prompt: Explain Newton's First Law to a 10-year-old.
all_candidates:
Sure! Newton’s First Law says that things like to keep doing what they are already doing.

If something is standing still, it wants to stay still. If something is moving, it wants to keep moving the same way. But things only change (start moving, stop, or change direction) if something pushes or pulls on them.

For example, if you kick a ball, it rolls until the grass and air slow it down and stop it. If there was nothing to stop it, it would keep rolling forever! That’s Newton’s First Law.

Sure! Newton’s First Law says that things like to keep doing what they’re already doing.

If something is sitting still, it will stay still unless you push or pull it.  
If something is moving, it will keep moving the same way unless you stop it or change its direction.

For example, if you leave your toy car on the floor, it won’t move unless you give it a push. And if you roll a ball, it keeps going until something like your foot or a wall stops it. 

So, things don’t start or stop moving all by themselves—something has to make them!

Sure! Newton's First Law says that things like to keep doing what they're already doing.

If something is standing still, it will stay still until something pushes or pulls it. If something is moving, it will keep moving the same way until something stops it, slows it down, or makes it turn.

For example, if you slide a toy car on the floor, it will keep rolling until it bumps into something or the floor makes it slow down and stop. That’s Newton’s First Law: things stay still or keep moving unless something makes them change.

Sure! Newton's First Law says that things like to keep doing what they're already doing. If something is still, it wants to stay still. If something is moving, it wants to keep moving in a straight line. Things only change if you push or pull them. 

For example, if you slide a toy car, it keeps going until something (like your hand or a wall) stops it. That "something" is a force. So, things don’t start or stop moving by themselves—they need a push or a pull!
selected_candidate:
Sure! Newton’s First Law says that things like to keep doing what they’re already doing.

If something is standing still, it will stay still unless you push or pull it. If something is moving, it will keep moving in the same way unless something (like a wall or your hand) stops it or changes its direction.

For example, if you slide a toy car across the floor, it keeps moving until it hits a wall or slows down because of the floor. That’s Newton’s First Law!
top_ranked_output:
Sure! Newton's First Law says that things like to keep doing what they're already doing.

If something is standing still, it will stay still until something pushes or pulls it. If something is moving, it will keep moving the same way until something stops it, slows it down, or makes it turn.

For example, if you slide a toy car on the floor, it will keep rolling until it bumps into something or the floor makes it slow down and stop. That’s Newton’s First Law: things stay still or keep moving unless something makes them change.
